text: We have begun to outline how artificial agents based upon free energy principle and active inference might be used to test cybernetic Big Five theories, theoretical propositions regarding the functional significance of the dimensions in the Big Five trait hierarchy, which is from psychology.

text: Here are the implications and why it matters from the author's conclusion as well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: If deep correspondences can be found between CB5T and FEP AI, as we suggest is likely to be the case due to their common cybernetic foundations, then this integration may allow personality modelers to obtain new understanding with respect to functions and then to parlay that understanding of function into new hypotheses about mechanisms in the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And, finally, identifying the configurations of personality mechanisms that correspond to effective cybernetic function may yield insights into how personality imbalances can lead to mental disorders, thereby furthering the aims of computational psychiatry and other attempts at developing theories of human mental health and well-being.

text: What about generative models?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Generative models can be contrasted with descriptive models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Descriptive models go from data, which are observations about the world, or results of an experiment, and go from data to then the modeling of parameters about the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So given the height of these 50 children, what is the mean and the variance of height in the classroom?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so statistics can be seen as a specific kind of dimensional reduction about measurements in the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, you have 50 measurements.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's a 50 dimensional vector.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then it's being reduced onto a mean and a variance component.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So two numbers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's like a bottleneck that only two numbers get to pass through.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a dimensional reduction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then you hope that those dimensions capture the average variance.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: uh value of the trait or whatever and the variability so that's going from data to the model dimensional reduction generative models go the other direction which is from the model's parameters
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: for example, the mean and the variance, to the expected data.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Given a mean and a variance estimate for height, the two numbers, can we generate sets of predicted measurements that are consistent?

text: So generate a draw of 50 children.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: it allows the system to use a lot of its previous knowledge on sparse data sets, because generative models might only need a slight cue to tip their likelihood from something being very unlikely to totally likely.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: For example, hearing the sound of an ambulance outside your window means that it's extremely likely that there is an ambulance there, even though it's also possible that there's one at other times.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: All right, big five, psychology.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the big five are dimensions of variation that are statistical and usually from self-reported surveys that are based upon basically personality differences in the population.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a dimension of variability in populations, kind of like the trait of heritability from quantitative genetics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's a measure of variance explained on a certain population sample.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's not a causal model of traits, nor is it a fraction due to genetic causes, even though that fallacy is made throughout the literature.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the Big Five is based upon the use of statistical methods, basically correlation matrices and principal component analyses, on survey data that finds patterns across questions and participants.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the acronym for Big Five is OCEAN.

text: So here's an example of how the big five are calculated and then what the oceans stand for.

text: A matrix is the likelihood mapping

text: The B matrix is the transition probabilities, or how dynamics are expected to evolve from one moment to the next.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: From the agent's perspective, this would correspond to answering the question, how do I believe things are likely to change through time?

text: Three, C matrix.

text: The C matrix is the prior beliefs over policies or outcomes or which states an agent predicts itself occupying.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Via mechanisms of prediction error minimization, these prior expectations constitute the attracting states of the system and function as preferences.
